title: In cellulo and in vivo assays for compound testing against Trypanosoma cruzi

Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Critical: All cell manipulations should be carried out under strict aseptic conditions and all solutions should be sterile.
Preparing a stock of infective T. cruzi trypomastigotes
Timing: 3–4 weeks
In this step, cell-derived trypomastigotes will be generated to be used in cell and animal infection experiments (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2388-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Overview of the preparation of the stock of infective T. cruzi trypomastigotes
Obtain metacyclic trypomastigotes from in vitro differentiation.7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7],9[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9]
Cultivate epimastigotes of the T. cruzi Dm28c strain expressing firefly luciferase in LIT medium for at least five days until late exponential growth phase (∼ 5 × 107 cells/mL);
Collect 5 × 108 cells by centrifugation at 6,000 × g for 15 min at 20°C–25°C;
Remove completely the supernatant and resuspend cells in 1 mL of triatomine artificial urine (TAU) medium (density of 5 × 108 cells/mL).
incubate for 2 h at 28°C to obtain stressed epimastigotes;
Prepare two 75 cm2 culture flasks containing 50 mL of TAU3AAG medium each and transfer 500 μL each of the stressed epimastigote suspension (final density of 5 × 106 cells/mL).
incubate at 28°C for 72 h;
After this time, recover the metacyclic trypomastigotes by centrifugation at 6,000 × g for 20 min at 10°C.
Suspend the metacyclic trypomastigotes in 1 mL of complete culture medium.
Determine the metacyclic trypomastigotes number using a hemocytometer and a light microscope. Proceed immediately to the next step.
Infect Vero cells with metacyclic trypomastigotes using a MOI of 100.
Mix 5 × 105 Vero cells (see preparing Vero cells for infection experiments[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.4]) with 5 × 107 metacyclic trypomastigotes recovered in the previous step.

Divide the mix of cells and parasites in two 75 cm2 culture flasks, complete the volume to 10 mL with complete culture medium and incubate at 37°C in a humid 5% CO2 environment.
After 24 h of infection, discard the medium and rinse 2 times with 10 mL of DPBS to remove all trypomastigotes that have not invaded the cells.
Add 10 mL of complete culture medium to each flask and incubate at 37°C in a humid 5% CO2 environment.
After 72 h of infection, replace the medium with fresh 10 mL of complete culture medium and incubate at 37°C in a humid 5% CO2 environment.
After 96 h of infection, recover cell-derived trypomastigotes by centrifugation at 3,000 × g for 20 min at 12°C.
Suspend parasites in 2 mL of complete culture medium and determine the trypomastigotes number as described above.
Critical: The first release of cell-derived trypomastigotes after an infection of Vero cells with metacyclic trypomastigotes can take more than 96 h. If the number of released parasites is less than 5 × 106 cells, add fresh 10 mL of medium to culture flasks and continue to incubate, monitoring daily until enough trypomastigotes have been released into the culture medium. See also troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] section (problem 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.3]).
Prepare infective cell-derived trypomastigotes using a MOI of 10.
Mix 5 × 105 Vero cells (see preparing Vero cells for infection experiments[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.4]) with 5 × 106 cell-derived trypomastigotes in a total of 20 mL of complete culture medium.
Divide into two 75 cm2 culture flask and incubate for 4 h at 37°C in a humid 5% CO2 environment.
Discard the medium and rinse 2 times with 10 mL of DPBS to remove all free trypomastigotes.
Add 10 mL of complete culture medium and incubate at 37°C in a humid 5% CO2 environment.

After 72 h of infection, replace the medium with a fresh 10 mL of complete culture medium and incubate again at 37°C in a humid 5% CO2 environment.
After 96 h of infection, recover the cell-derived trypomastigotes by centrifugation at 3,000 × g for 20 min at 12°C.
Critical: To achieve higher infection rates for the intended assays, perform at least three cycles of reinfection with cell-derived trypomastigotes before storage. See also troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] section (problem 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.3]).
Store infective cell-derived trypomastigotes in liquid nitrogen.
Suspend the cell-derived trypomastigotes in the appropriate volume of 10% DMSO in FBS (v/v), to reach a concentration of 5 × 106 cells/mL.
Transfer 1 mL to each cryotube.
Put the cryotubes in a CoolCell container and place it in a −80°C freezer for 24 h.
Alternatives: If a CoolCell container or similar is not available, it is possible to freeze the cryotubes in a small Styrofoam box for 4 h at −20°C and then for 20 h at −80°C.
Store the frozen cryotubes under liquid nitrogen.
Critical: Repeat steps 3 and 4 until there are at least 30 frozen vials of 5 × 106 cell-derived trypomastigotes. This is particularly important to keep experiments running continuously without having to prepare cell-derived trypomastigotes for each round of testing. Alternatively, it is possible to expand the number of flasks at the same time to have more cell-derived trypomastigotes, minimizing batch to batch variations.
Compound testing in cell infection assays – Phase I: Preliminary screening for exclusion of non-active and toxic compounds
Timing: 10 days

In this step, the compounds are tested using cell infection assays in a single curve with a sparse number of concentration points. Compound testing in cell infection assays is very laborious and time consuming. Therefore, this approach is particularly interesting for a first screen, when a large number of compounds must be tested, allowing for exclusion of compounds non-active against T. cruzi and of compounds toxic for the host cells in parallel with pre-selection of those with higher intracellular T. cruzi inhibition for deeper investigation of their activity profile (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2388-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Overview of the compound testing – Phase I strategy
Critical: Vero cells will be used throughout all the procedure, so it will be necessary always to keep them in culture (see maintaining Vero cells culture[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.3]).
Note: In this work, the amount of Vero cells and trypomastigotes are calculated for testing 28 different compounds (a total of 4 plates) but adjustments can be made according to the number of compounds to be tested in parallel.
Alternatives: In this work, all pipetting was done manually, but if available, it is possible to use automatic liquid dispensing robots.
Day 1:
Thaw a frozen vial containing 5 × 106 cell-derived trypomastigotes for obtention of fresh infective trypomastigotes.
Thaw rapidly by gentle agitation in a 37°C water bath and remove just before the content is fully thawed.
Note: To reduce the possibility of contamination, keep the O-ring and cap above the water.
Transfer the trypomastigotes to a centrifuge tube containing 9 mL of complete culture medium and centrifuge at 3,000 × g for 20 min at 12°C.
Discard the supernatant.
Suspend the trypomastigotes in 1 mL of complete culture medium.

Mix 5 × 105 Vero cells (see Obtaining Vero cells for infection experiments[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.4]) with the trypomastigotes (5 × 106 parasites) in a 75 cm2 culture flask, complete the volume to 10 mL with complete culture medium and incubate for 4 h at 37°C in a humid 5% CO2 environment.
After 4 h of infection, discard the medium and rinse 2 times with 10 mL of DPBS to remove all the parasites that have not invaded the cells.
Add 10 mL of complete culture medium and incubate for 96 h at 37°C in a humid 5% CO2 environment.
Day 3:
In parallel, maintain a Vero cell culture for the next steps.
Inoculate 3,5 × 105 Vero cells in 10 mL of complete culture medium in a 75 cm2 culture flask (see maintaining Vero cells[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.3] and preparing Vero cells for infection experiments[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.4]).
Incubate at 37°C in a humid 5% CO2 environment.
Day 5:
At late afternoon, discard the medium of the infected cells (from step 8) and rinse 2 times with 10 mL of DPBS to remove all trypomastigotes that have already been released, aiming to minimize new cycles of infection.
Add 10 mL of complete culture medium and incubate at 37°C in a humid 5% CO2 environment.
Day 6:
In the morning, collect the released trypomastigotes by transferring the supernatant to a centrifuge tube.
Recover the cell-derived trypomastigotes from the supernatant by centrifugation at 3,000 × g for 20 min at 12°C.
Suspend the parasites in 2 mL of complete culture medium and store at 4°C until the time of use.
add 10 mL of complete culture medium to the cell layer in the culture flask and incubate at 37°C in a humid 5% CO2 environment for another cycle of trypomastigote release.

Still in the morning, using the cells seeded at step 9 (see preparing Vero cells for infection experiments[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.4]), dilute the appropriate quantity of Vero cells in complete culture medium to have 2 × 104 cells/mL (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2388-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Plating of Vero cells for the compound screening assay
QUANTITY OF CELLS: 2,000 cells per well × 60 wells × 4 plates × 1.2 (20% extra volume) = 5.76 × 105 cells.
TOTAL VOLUME: 100 μL per well × 60 wells × 4 plates × 1.2 (20% extra volume) = 28.8 mL.
Note: To ensure that the volume will be sufficient until the end of pipetting, it is recommended to make the calculations with an extra volume. In this work, we use a factor of 1.2 (20% of extra volume).
Using a multichannel pipette, transfer 100 μL of Vero cells (2 × 104 cells/mL) to each well of four 96-wells culture plates as indicated in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]. Incubate at 37°C in a humid 5% CO2 environment.
Do not use the wells of the border rows of the plate as they could not be properly analyzed by the automated imaging system but do not leave them empty. Add 100 μL of PBS at cell-free wells.
Note: If other types of culture plates and automated imaging system provide good images from the edge wells, allowing for proper analysis, it is possible to use the edge wells. However, additional attention should be taken with evaporation issues.
Note: In the steps using a multichannel pipette, use a sterile multichannel pipette tray or a sterile 9 cm diameter culture plate to keep the cell suspension.

In the afternoon, recover the cell-derived trypomastigotes from the supernatant of cell culture from step 12b by centrifugation at 3,000 × g for 20 min at 12°C. Suspend parasites in 2 mL of complete culture medium.
Count the trypomastigotes from both parasite suspensions (“morning” from step 12a and “afternoon” from step 15) using a hemocytometer and a light microscope.
Verify if the quantity of trypomastigotes recovered from step 15 (“afternoon” parasites) is sufficient for the total needed in the next step. If not, combine with the trypomastigotes recovered from step 12a (“morning”).
Critical: If the total quantity of parasites is not enough for the next step, abort the experiment and restart from step 5 (see also problem 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.3]).
Infect Vero cells with a MOI of 20. For this, dilute the appropriate quantity of trypomastigotes in complete culture medium to a concentration of 4 × 105 trypomastigotes/mL (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2388-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Infection of cells for screening assay
QUANTITY OF TRYPOMASTIGOTES: 20 (MOI) × 2,000 cells per well × 54 wells × 4 plates × 1.2 extra volume = 1.0368 × 107 trypomastigotes.
TOTAL VOLUME: 100 μL per well × 54 wells × 4 plates × 1.2 extra volume = 25.92 mL.
Using a multichannel pipette, transfer 100 μL of trypomastigotes (4 × 105 trypomastigotes/mL) to each cell-containing well of the 96-well plate, except for the wells of the plate border rows and for the wells of non-infected control cells as indicated in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4].
Add 100 μL of complete culture medium to the non-infected control wells.
Incubate the plates for 16 h–20 h at 37°C in a humid 5% CO2 environment.
Day 7:

After 16 h of infection, carefully discard the supernatant by aspirating with a pipette. Rinse each well with 150 μL of DPBS to remove all trypomastigotes that have not invaded the cells.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2388-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Detail of the washing procedure
Aspirate and dispense the liquid by touching the tip to the wall of the well, in a circular movement to ensure complete washing, and taking care not to touch the bottom. Pipette slowly so as not to disturb the cell layer.
Critical: Aspirate and dispense the liquid by touching the tip to the wall of the well and taking care not to touch the bottom as indicated in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]. Pipette slowly so as not to disturb the cell layer.
Carefully remove all remaining DPBS. Add 100 μL of complete culture medium to each cell-containing well (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]) and incubate at 37°C in a humid 5% CO2 environment.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2388-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. Addition of complete culture medium after washing
Prepare the compounds for treatment:
Using 0.2 mL tubes, dilute the compounds in DMSO so to have a 5-fold dilution curve ranging from 10 mM to 3.2 μM as indicated in Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2388-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. Pre-dilution of compounds
Distribute 100 μL of complete culture medium to four new 96-well.
add 1 μL of each one of the 28 pre-diluted compounds as indicated in Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]. Mix well.

Critical: It is not recommended to use more than 1% final DMSO in the cultures since it can be toxic to cells.
Alternatives: To reduce pipetting errors of small volumes, it is possible to increase the volumes as long as the final DMSO concentration in the cultures is maintained at a maximum of 1%.

Treat cells (from step 22) as indicated in Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9] using a different set of compounds (BZN + 7 test compounds) for each culture plate from step 22.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2388-Fig9.jpg

Figure 10. Outline of a 28-compound assay in four culture plates including non-infected and untreated controls, reference drug benznidazole and the 28 compounds
NI: non infected Vero cells; NT: untreated infected Vero cells; Bzn: reference drug benznidazole in infected Vero cells and C1 – C28: 28 different compounds in wells with infected Vero cells.
to the non-infected and untreated control wells, add 100 μL of 1% DMSO in complete culture medium.
to the reference drug (BZN) and compound test wells, add 100 μL of the dilutions prepared in the step 23b.
Note: At this point each well contains 200 μL of culture medium and 0.5% of DMSO. The compound distribution in the plates with the final dilutions is shown in Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10].
Incubate all four 96-well culture plates treated with the compounds for 48 h at 37°C in a humid 5% CO2 environment.
Day 9:
After 48 h of treatment, carefully discard the supernatant by aspirating with a pipette.
Rinse each well with 150 μL of DPBS as indicated in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5].
Add 100 μL of 4% paraformaldehyde in DPBS and incubate for 15 min at 20°C–25°C.
Discard and rinse with 150 μL of DPBS.
Add 100 μL of cell dye solution to each well, incubate for 15 min at 25°C and read on an Operetta System.
Note: At this stage the plates can be stored at 4°C for several days until reading. We analyzed plates stored for 3 weeks just checking before for crystal formations.

Critical: If there is crystal formation in the bottom of the plates due to DAPI/Evans blue aggregation, wash the plates 3 times with PBS prior to image acquisition. This can happen mainly when using a low-quality paraformaldehyde and storage for longer periods (more than 3 weeks).
Proceed to the section “processing of cell infection images using the Operetta System[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec5.1]” for data analysis.
Compound testing in cell infection assays – Phase II: Intracellular T. cruzi inhibition assay to determine IC50, CC50 and selectivity index (SI) and selection of candidates for in vivo testing
Timing: 10 days
In this section, the compounds selected from phase I are tested with replicates, in a wider concentration range and, if needed different treatment times, in order to obtain consistent data for reliable IC50, CC50 and selectivity index calculation with statistical support, allowing for appropriate estimation of compound efficiency against intracellular T. cruzi (Figure 11[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig11]).

Plate distribution for each treatment. Positioning of the 10 diluted compound concentrations, expressed as μM or nM. 24 h, 48 h and 72 h: treatment time.
Critical: Vero cells will be used throughout the whole procedure, so it is required always to keep them in culture (see maintaining Vero cells[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.3] culture).
Note: In this section, the volume of cell and parasite are calculated for testing 3 different compounds using 10 different concentrations in quadruplicates for each compound concentration and 3 treatment times making a total of 9 plates, but adjustments can be made according to specific requirements. This arrangement allows for testing one compound per 96-well plate in parallel with untreated controls and non-infected cells on the same plate to reduce variation of culture conditions and experimental manipulations.

Divide the mix of Vero and parasites cells in two 75 cm2 culture flask, complete the volume of each to 10 mL with complete culture medium and incubate for 4 h at 37°C in a humid 5% CO2 environment.
After 4 h of infection, discard the medium and rinse 2 times with 10 mL of DPBS to remove all the parasites that have not invaded the cells.
Add 10 mL of complete culture medium to each flask and incubate at 37°C in a humid 5% CO2 environment.
Day 3:
In parallel, maintain a Vero cell culture for next steps. T. cruzi inhibition assay in mouse infection model
Timing: 10 days
In this step, the compounds will be tested and compared in parallel with the reference drug benznidazole using animal model (Figure 19[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig19]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2388-Fig19.jpg

Critical: Before starting this section, permission for the use of animals should have already been obtained from an Animal Experimentation Ethics Committee and the mice should be available. See also before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin] Section - obtaining mice for infection and compound testing[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.6].
Note: In this work, all the animal experiments were carried out at the Animal Facility of FIOCRUZ ICC Paraná (Laboratory of Animal Models – LACEA) which is responsible to provide housing and husbandry. Specific Pathogens Free (SPF) animals, obtained from certified matrices imported from the Charles River laboratory – USA, are kept under aseptic conditions. All animals – individually identified and grouped according to their respective treatment, with a maximum of 5 animals per cage – are kept inside sterile ventilated racks and are always handled within laminar flows ensuring their sanitary integrity.
Thaw a frozen vial containing 5 × 106 cell-derived trypomastigotes for amplification and obtention of fresh infective trypomastigotes.
Thaw rapidly by gentle agitation in a 37°C water bath and remove just before the content is fully thawed.
Note: To reduce the possibility of contamination, keep the O-ring and cap above the water.
Transfer the trypomastigotes to a centrifuge tube containing 9 mL of complete culture medium.
Centrifuge at 3,000 × g for 20 min at 12°C.
Discard the supernatant.
Suspend the parasites in 1 mL of complete culture medium.
Infect 5 × 105 Vero cells (see Obtaining Vero cells for infection experiments[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.4]) with thawed trypomastigotes (5 × 106 parasites) as described in step 3.
Infection day:
Recover cell-derived trypomastigote from the previous step and suspend parasites in DPBS to obtain 106 cells/mL.
Prepare an appropriate volume for all inoculations: final volume = (100 μL per mouse) × [(number of mice per condition) × (number of conditions: untreated, reference drug benznidazole and test compound) + 2∗].

Note: ∗ 2 extra doses for syringe dead volume.
Note: T. cruzi strains present distinct virulence and require different amounts of parasites to cause an adequate acute infection and subsequent detection. The indicated parasite load of 105 parasites/mouse was standardized for T. cruzi Dm28c strain.
Inoculate 100 μL of infective parasites intraperitoneally in each mouse (Figure 20[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig20]).

Critical: Animal handling and inoculations should be performed exclusively by trained personnel with prior expertise.
Day 3 post infection:
Acquire pre-treatment mice images.
Prepare D-luciferin for inoculations considering the recommended concentration of 150 mg/kg:
Weight the mice and calculate the average weight.
Weight D-luciferin for all inoculations: total quantity = (average of mice weight in kg) × [(number of mice per condition) × (number of conditions (untreated, reference drug benznidazole and test compound)) + 2∗] × 150 mg/kg.
Dilute the D-luciferin in DPBS in an appropriate volume for all inoculations: final volume = 100 μL per mouse × [(number of mice per condition) × (number of conditions (untreated, reference drug benznidazole and test compound)) + 2∗].
Note: ∗ 2 extra doses for syringe dead volume.
Administer 100 μL of D-luciferin in the intraperitoneal cavity of the mice and wait for 8 min.
Anesthetize the mice.
Adjust the oxygen flowmeter to 0.4–0.8 l/min in a box chamber and isoflurane vaporizer to 2.5% and wait for 2 min.
Place the animals in the nosecone of the image acquisition equipment, maintaining the anesthetizing gas and oxygen during the entire process.
Acquire images of pre-treatment mice on ventral and dorsal positions using an IVIS Spectrum CT scanner (other luminescence living image scanners could be used) within 10–15 min after D-luciferin inoculation.
Take both auto and 30 s timed acquisitions.

Ensure that the positioning of animals is reproduced in each acquisition, with the animals being placed in the same order.
Critical: The time interval between D-luciferin inoculation and image acquisition is critical for proper comparison between groups. Ensure that the delayed time for anesthetizing and positioning animals on the IVIS is reproducible to minimize processing differences between groups. This time interval should be previously tested to determine the peak signal intensity and the time window. We found no significant difference in the 10–15 min interval.
Note: If no signal was detected at this stage, please refer to problem 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.15]: in troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] session.
Note: Images are processed using the Living Image software. See description on Section quantification and statistical analysis[href=https://www.wicell.org#quantification-and-statistical-analysis] - processing of images using the Living Image Software[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec5.3].
Day 4 post infection:
Dilute compounds just prior to administration.
Solubilize the weighted and aliquoted compounds (from Section: preparing compounds and reference drug for mice treatment[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.7]) in DMSO so the final concentration is 7% and mix well.
Add 50% HP-β-cyclodextrin prepared in DPBS so the final concentration is 40% and mix well.
Complete volume with DPBS.
Treat each group of mice with intraperitoneal injection of 100 μL of the diluted compounds or vehicle for the control group (Figure 21[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig21]).
